meaning.exp: Logical connective: sumti afterthought or. Connects two sumti, such that the containing bridi is true if and only if it is true for at least one of the connected sumti.
meaning.note: Supplanted with {{ja}} in JACU.

example.lojban: .i xu mi klama lo mu'a ceizda {{.a}} lo mu'a pacraistu
example.english: Do I go to, say, heaven {{or}} hell?
example.author: Andy Weir

meaning.exp: Letteral for a. When used alone, refers to the most recent sumti starting with {{a}}.

example.lojban: .i ro da sutra fa'a {{la .alis.}} ca lo nu {{.a bu}} tolcanci
example.english: They all made a rush at {{Alice}} the moment {{she}} (= Alice) appeared.
example.author: Lewis Carroll

meaning.exp: Equivalent to {{.i pau}}. Starts a sentence that is by default a question.
meaning.note: Adopting ajbo prerequires adopting JACU. A sentence started with {{.a}} always contains a question marker ({{xu}}, {{ma}}, {{mo}} etc.)

example.lojban: {{.a xu}} do pu zi mo'u gunka tu'a lo do jibri
example.english: Did you just finished your job{{?}}
example.speaker: la srasu

example.lojban: {{.anai}} la loglan cu jbobau xu .i na go'i ni'i loka lujvo {{.a xu}} ku'i la loglan cu lojbo bangu
example.english: Are Loglan Lojban{{?}} It's not because of the lujvo [structure]. But is Loglan some kind of Lojban-ic language{{?}}
example.speaker: la melmi
example.note: The first sentence seems to be a question where the speaker is asking themselves or is expecting a negative answer, but it's hard to say for sure because there are no other instences of {{.anai}} in similar usage.

meaning.exp: Starts a response to a question.

example.lojban:
— .i nancaji li xo
— {{.anai}} reze
example.english:
— How old are you (in years)?
— Twenty-seven.
example.speaker: la nonselcme, la srasu
example.note: The former sentence is compatible with CLL Lojban. The latter is in ajbo.

meaning.exp: Starts a rhetorical question.
meaning.note: This meaning is only attested once, making it a hapax. This usage is listed separately because this usage is mentioned (but not used) by other speakers.

example.lojban: {{.anai}} la catra cu catra xu zo'o
example.english: Does "Killer" kill{{? /j}}
example.note: This is the only instance of {{.a nai}} being used as a rhetorical question starter.
example.speaker: .kúblizel.

meaning.exp: attitudinal: attentive - inattentive - avoiding.
attitudinal: alertness - exhaustion.
attitudinal: effort - no special effort - repose.
Attitudinal: express intent / purpose / design.

example.lojban: .i {{.ai}} mi ba snada ro se troci
example.english: I{{'ll}} succeed in everything I try.
example.author: Djemynai

meaning.exp: Attitudinal: express indecision / hesitation / vacillation / wavering.

example.lojban: ― .i pu zi co'i mo'u tinzga 100 zo'e .ibo ca surla .i {{.aicu'i}} tinzga lo velvi'u 400mei
example.english: ― Just finished listening to the first 100 and am now taking a break. {{Unsure if}} I'll listen to the remaining 400.
example.speaker: la lalxu

meaning.exp: Attitudinal: express rejection / refusal.
meaning.note: BPFK proposed changing it to "express unintention / accidentiality", but I didn't find usage of that.

example.lojban: .i go pu'o zei ganlo se morji gi ne'i la'e di'u milxe bacru za'a sei {{.ai nai}} tolmo'i
example.english: The unclosed memories, I hear whispers inside them that {{we never want to}} forget.
example.author: Youmi Kimura

meaning.exp: $x_1$ intends to do/be $x_2$ (ka).
Attitudinal: express hope / longing.

example.lojban: .i a'o ro da zabna
example.english: {{I hope}} everything is good.
example.author: la .cogas.

meaning.exp: Attitudinal: express despair / hopelessness / dread / fear.

example.lojban: .i le trene pu zi co'a cliva se ka'a lo tcadu poi darno {{.a'o nai}}
example.english: The train's just started to leave for the faraway city, {{oh no...}}
example.author: inabakumori

meaning.exp: vocative: slightly piratical greetings
Attitudinal: express interest / curiosity / concern / preoccupation.

example.lojban: .i {{.a'u sai}} .i ti lo nu mi sipna cu fanmo
example.english: {{Cool,}} this is the end of my sleep.
example.author: Djemynai

meaning.exp: Attitudinal: express disinterest / uninterest / unconcern / apathy / detachment / indifference.

example.lojban: {{.a'ucu'i}} .i ka'u mi'o na ba se fatri lo do'anai bongu .oi
example.english: {{Whatever.}} Now he won't even share the bones with us anyway...
example.author: Kenji Miyazawa

meaning.exp: Attitudinal: express repulsion / aversion / disgust / distaste / repugnance.

example.lojban: {{.a'u nai}} bu'o pilno lo do voksa
example.english: I {{don't want to}} use your voice anymore!
example.author: ryo

gloss: Grouping: short scope link, strong binding

meaning.exp: Short scope link. Used in various grammatical constructions and acts as a high precedence link, overriding usual left-grouping rules. Chains linked with {{bo}} are grouped to the right. Specific usages are explained below.
Joins tanru units, binding them together closely.

example.lojban: ni'o ze mo'o fenki tcati {{bo}} kansi'u
example.english: VII. The mad tea{{-}}party
example.note: The {{bo}} directly corresponds to the hyphen in the English text. Without the {{bo}} the tanru will group as {{[fenki tcati] kansi'u}}, which roughly translates to "the mad-tea party".
example.author: Lewis Carroll

meaning.exp: Override the default left-grouping in chained connectives. Constituents connected by connectives with {{bo}} are grouped first. Chains linked with {{bo}} are grouped to the right.

example.lojban: .i ku'i mi pu ku tcidu ba'e so'u pagbu be le to'e censa se ciska gi'e ba bo ga'orgau le cukta {{gi'e bo}} co'a bevri
example.english: Yet I had read only the least fragment of that blasphemous rune before closing the book and bringing it away.
example.note: The English sentence is grouped as "I had read... before [closing the book and bringing it away]". If the underlined {{bo}} wasn't there, it'll group as "I had [read... before closing the book] and bringing it away". This example also shows the right-grouping rule with chained {{bo}}: The {{gi'e ba bo}} in the example has a lower priority because it is to the left of the underlined {{gi'e bo}}.
example.author: H. P. Lovecraft

meaning.context: Between a NAhE and a sumti
meaning.exp: Binds NAhE and the sumti together.
meaning.note: Not required in later grammars such as camxes beta or zantufa.

example.lojban: .i mi ka'e binxo lo makcu prenu noi se cinri no {{na'e bo}} lo namcu
example.english: I may become like the grown-ups who are interested in anything nothing {{other than}} figures.
example.author: Antoine de Saint-Exupéry

meaning.exp: Forms a sentence link along with {{.i}} and the BAI modal. The resulting sentence link ({{.i BAI bo}}) tags the latter bridi as a whole by the BAI modal, and incorporates it to the former (main) bridi. {{BRIDI<sub>1</sub> .i BAI bo BRIDI<sub>2</sub>}} has a similar meaning to {{BRIDI<sub>1</sub> BAI lo su'u BRIDI<sub>2</sub>}} or {{lo su'u BRIDI<sub>2</sub> cu SELBRI lo su'u BRIDI<sub>1</sub>}} (where {{BAI}} is the modal for {{SELBRI}}), but {{.i BAI bo}} also asserts that both the linked bridi are true.

example.lojban: ni'o lo ka jinga nalka'e cu nalvai {{.i mu'i bo}} mi klama be tu mutce bo djica
example.english: It doesn't matter that I can't win, {{because}} I really want to go there.
example.note: The second {{bo}} in this example is of another usage (that inside a tanru).
example.author: Ibuki Tsubasa

meaning.exp: Forms a sentence link along with {{.i}} and the tense. The resulting sentence link ({{.i TENSE bo}}) tags the latter bridi as a whole by the opposite of the tense, and incorporates it to the former (main) bridi. {{BRIDI1 .i TENSE bo BRIDI2}} has a similar meaning to {{BRIDI2 TENSE lo su'u BRIDI1}}, but {{.i TENSE bo}} also asserts that both the linked bridi are true.
meaning.note: The implication of the relationship between connected sentences is the opposite for modals and tenses. The reason is likely historical, as said in Lojban for Beginners (p. 110): "The very astute reader will have noted that ‘afterwards’ should have been {{.i pu bo}}; the analogy with {{ba ku}} won out, though."

example.lojban: .e'u mi'o klama lo korbi {{.i ba bo}} mi do jungau lo lisri be mi
example.english: Let us get to the shore, {{and then}} I'll let you know my story.
example.author: Lewis Carroll

meaning.context: After a connective and a BAI modal
meaning.exp: Binds the connective and the model so that the model signifies the relation between the connected elements. {{.i je BAI bo}} are similar in meaning to {{.i BAI bo}}, and the meanings of other connectives can inferred analogously.
meaning.note: This usage is not unique to {{bo}}. Other grouping words like {{ke}} can also do this, but only those with {{bo}} are attested.

example.lojban: .i ca ro dunra lo clika co'a dunja {{je ja'e bo}} sligu
example.english: Every winter the moss freezes {{and becomes}} solid {{as a result}}.
example.author: Ryan Cross on Science

meaning.context: After a connective and a tense
meaning.exp: Binds the connective and the tense so that the tense signifies the time relation between the connected elements. {{.i je TENSE bo}} are similar in meaning to {{.i TENSE bo}}, and the meanings of other connectives can inferred analogously.
meaning.note: This usage is not unique to {{bo}}. Other grouping words like {{ke}} can also do this, but only those with {{bo}} are attested.

example.lojban: .i loi sorska cinta ko fi ko'a cu se punji {{.i je ba bo}} loi xekri tabno ko'a gacri
example.english: Paint it with colorful pigments, {{and soon enough}} it'll be covered in black charcoal.
example.author: Noise and Bells

meaning.exp: Forms a sentence link along with {{.i}}. The resulting sentence link separates bridi, but doesn't reset bridi level. Multiple bridi separated with {{.i bo}} shares the same prenex.
meaning.note: The above explanation is taken from roljbogu'e chatlog, under said explanation {{.i bo}} is analogous to {{.i je}}. In actual usage, however, {{.i bo}} often resets bridi level, making {{.i ji'a}} a closer analogue.

example.lojban: .i .e'u nai cai la nicte cadzu ba mulno spogau lo se terpa {{da poi fanva dei lo na logji bangu}}
example.english: WARNING! Night Walker will bring complete destruction by something scary to {{those who translate this into a non-logical language.}}
example.note: Those who are keen on quantification will notice that this sentence uses existential quantification on {{da poi ...}}, which means if there are multiple translators, only "at least one of them" will be destroyed, instead of "all" which is suggested by the content of the text. (Such interpretation would be accomplished with universal quantification {{ro da poi ...}}). Actually, the {{da}} is being used here as a generic pronoun, which is a common usage in texts from the 2000s.
example.author: Robin Lee Powell

meaning.exp: Connective: connective question. Connects two grammatical constructs of the same type and asks the listener to supply a connective that makes the containing bridi true.

example.lojban:
― coi jbope'o mi'e zi sipna
― puzi {{ji}} bazi
― naje li'abu'o u'i
example.english:
― Hello Lojban friends, I'm sleeping (from a short distance in time from now)
― To the past {{or}} to the future?
― The latter, should be obvious now, haha.
example.speaker: la srasu, la evis
example.note: The middle sentence would be {{puzi <u>je'i</u> bazi}} under CLL Lojban.

meaning.exp: Discursive: indicate an additional case or additional cases.

Name article. Converts a selbri, selecting its first argument, or any string of cmevla into a sumti.
meaning.note: The resulting expression refers specifically to an individual or individuals that the speaker has in mind and which the speaker names with the selbri or cmevla.

example.lojban: coi {{la na'e vajni ku}} noi je'a vajni
example.english: Hello {{Not Important}}, who is indeed important!
example.note: "Not Important" is the name of the person greeted. Note the {{ku}} in this expression: it closes the selbri name. if the {{ku}} wasn't there the name selbri becomes {{na'e vajni noi je'a vajni}}, in which the relative clause becomes part of the name.
example.speaker: Lucilla

example.lojban:
— .i ma jmina le jugbau jufra le kibypapri
— {{la .lukifer.kailus.delikatus.}} no'u {{la .yu'orb.}}
example.english:
— Who added the Chiese sentences to the webpage?
— {{Lucifer Caelius Delicatus}} a.k.a. {{Yuorb}}
example.note: Specifically chosen to showcase cmevla chaining, where multiple cmevla in a row functions as a single name. Also note the answer parses differently in regards to CBM: with CBM {{.lukifer.kailus.delikatus. no'u la .yu'orb.}} is a name; without CBM {{no'u la .yu'orb.}} is a relative phrase of {{la .lukifer.kailus.delikatus.}} signifying the equivalence between them. Also note {{yu'orb}} is not a standard Lojban cmevla because of the {{y}}.
example.speaker: la nalvai, la ilmen

meaning.context: when used with an inner quantifier

Opens a parenthetical note. The text inside must be grammatical Lojban. Terminate with {{toi}}.
meaning.note: The text inside contains additional information that isn't essential to the meaning of the sentence, but can still help.

example.lojban: .i mi djuno ri'a lo su'u mi cmima le jatna kamni pe la logbau skejgu {{to la'o gy ~ The Loglan Institute ~ gy toi}}
example.english: I know, because I'm a member of the leader comitee associated with the science institute of Loglan {{([English] ~ The Loglan Institute ~)}}
example.speaker: la janbe

example.lojban: le mi bruna {{to se rirni le se rirni pe le mamta pe le mi mamta toi}} cu bilma
example.english: My brother, {{(my mother's mother's child's child)}} is ill.
example.speaker: la kanis
example.note: Note that the {{toi}} in this sentence is elidable, as the content in the parentheses cannot take the second selbri introduced by {{cu}}.

example.lojban: .i da'i {{to se va'u lo nu darlu toi}} lo jmive je pensi cu kakne lo nu zasti ze'o lo bitmu be lo botpi
example.english: ..., granting {{(for the sake of argument)}} that life and thought exist beyond the walls of the caraffe.
example.note: If the {{toi}} was elided in this sentence, the parentheses will automatically close just before the {{cu}}, for the same reason as in the previous example.
example.author: Robert Louis Stevenson
